message: what's the cost percentage you add to give your client the project source code ?

data.message:
negotiable with no up or down limits
also depends on many factors such as:
1- project nature... if it is a tailored solution specifically designed for the customer, then you can start from 20% up to 100% ... if it is a one of your flag products that you sell then you can start from 500% up to 1000% if you like ... no limits in this case
2- level and quality of code documentation...
there are no rules or specific answer for your question... put assumptions and hypothesis to have a wide range in your negotiation
I was thinking about this matter today, I don't understand how this works. So, do you usually give the client a minified version of the code?
Unless it is a product you sell, I don't really understand why wouldn't you give he client the source code. I am not criticising, I just don't get it.
My customer own their project's source code. I'd make them a discount to be able to reuse the code or resell it etc.

+1 to Meligy's answer. 
A. If you were hired as a freelancer/contractor to build something "for" the client, then the intellectual property: the product, design, code, etc.. is theirs and not yours. Client is paying for your working hours, so anything coming out of those working hours, technically the client owns. 
That's the convention I know of, so unless otherwise agreed, you generally need THEIR permission to reuse the solution/sell it and not the other way around.

B. If it was "your" product or service in the first place and you're just selling / providing them with version of it, customized or not, then it's your property and can negotiate selling it at a price.
Case B could also apply to a "part" of the product you're building for  the client, so let's say some core library/module you have already built in the past (on your own time) that will be included in your end solution. This isn't owned by the client because they didn't pay you to build it, so that's basically the rule of thumb
